The 1% will have been – correct me if I'm wrong – is that will be the guidance whatever we guide you on – would have guide you on 2010 for the full year or 2011 will be increased by 1% because of the inclusion of the FEMSA businesses.
And final one, 2011 you are -
Can you -
Okay.

And finally, Jean, your peers are indicating that raw material input cost in aggregate, not only barley, in 2011 should be flat or thereabout. You also fairly progressed in terms of your outlook for 2011. Could you confirm that you'll face a similar situation?

We cannot confirm that. We will give the guidance in February. As you say, there are many more elements than just barley; there is energy cost, which influence bottle prices; there is aluminum, et cetera. So we are not going to comment on that now.
But you're fairly well progressed in terms of your forward buying, et cetera, across all raw materials?

Yes, the normal progress is progressing. What I said earlier is that on the barley prices, it is better track but it's not going to be an enormous hike, as the current market situation would suggest. Nor there is a physical reason for doing so in the malted barley market and this is still a big, big enforcement.

As René said, the energy prices are never totally predictable. There also you hedge part of it, but, no, I never think so. We're not going to give you an absolute guarantee that it's going to stay flat, that's what we're basically saying, without expecting big hikes.
Thank you very much.
All right, last question.

Hi, it's Adam Spielman from Citigroup. It's a question about Western Europe and the outlook. In this period you just reported, your profit has gone up little over €20 million, in absolute euros. But you've got cost savings from the TCM program of about – of a bit over €50 million. Does that mean to say that without the cost savings, profit would have gone down? And that causes me to ask two questions.

Firstly, the observation that without the TCM program, the margin would have declined, which I find slightly strange as you said the main weakness in Europe or a lot of weakness was to do with the wholesalers with sort of low margins, and as I would have thought, as a proportion of your business, which is the core brewing, which is higher margin got bigger as your margins would have increased. So that's the question.

And the second question is, am I right to understand that as we think about Western Europe going forward, as far as one can see, we should expect sort of fundamental weakness offset by ongoing cost savings. And the sort of passion you've produced in the first half is something that we can expect to see really while the economy remains as it is, which is pretty weak in Western Europe.

The way you have to look at Europe is, for sure, cost reductions is an integral part of managing that region. So it's not you have here the cost saving and there you have the European business. No, it's part of doing that business, right-sizing your infrastructure to the realities of the market. At the same time, we should realize that Europe is a very strong consumer market. It's a very rich market. You see that we make lot of money, we make a very strong cash flow out of Europe and we need to invest in that market to take bigger share of a slightly shrinking pie.

And in the midst of the crisis, we have been quite reluctant to put in many new initiatives, new innovations, new brands, et cetera. But going forward, in the European market, you will not only rely on cost savings, now you will further rely likely that in the past before the crisis in getting more value out of the market, increasing your market share, be innovative, get more premium products in the market and that's the way forward for Europe. Absolutely, it's not only a cost-saving exercise, but cost savings is part of the game in Western Europe. Corner, yeah.
So, you really want to have the last question, okay. No, sure, no, I mean, it's not going fair.

You've got a sparkling new brewery in South Africa with 3 million hectoliters. You're raising that to 4.5 million hectoliters. What are you doing to absorb the fixed costs of production that South African production in Europe? Is that those beer hectoliters were produced in Europe? Isn't that weighing on your European margins this particular half-year?

Fair questions. To a certain extent, yes, but not really very material. When we took back our brands in South African production of – for Amstel, we have been allocating that to three breweries in Europe, France, Italy and Netherlands. We have been looking where we had the overcapacity. And we have meant – in terms of technical overcapacity, and we have meant that by flexible labor contracts.

So what costs you money is manned capacity. Unmanned capacity is just a price depreciation of stainless steel. So that's how we built the temporary business model on a kind of very calculated marginal base across Europe.

So, the effect, yes, you lose, of course, on the one side; you gain more on the other side, but you lose slightly on the depreciations part, which is not anymore supported by volume in Western Europe. But frankly, this is not a lot, and we have been dismantling that quite well. And then, it comes back to Western Europe. We have to go with the volumes.

We have – the name of the game, and I've said that many times, it's certainly production capacity. You make 100, you think that the market is going to be, let's say, 80 – and this is just an example, it's going to be 80 in ten years time. Make sure that you have dismantled your capacity to 80 in five years time and then you will have a gap to fill, but you're going to fill that up with increased productivity anyhow because we see for 18 years in a row that we'll make productivity progresses in our supply chain still. That's the good news, right.

So we take that view of having a pro-active capacity dismantling, if you will, and it goes also together with the lifecycles of the investments and hence we can do that and we took that. And one has to take the view on the European market to complement what René said. The brutal truth is that we do not have a demographic growth in the continent. And the baby boomers are graying, right. So they are retiring from consumption certainly and perhaps from life altogether. So the -
Be a bit optimistic.

I'm afraid that it is the bare reality of it today. But the thing is that – and of course, we – all fast-moving consumer goods can make these calculations. We are a proximity business essentially. So we produce in the neighborhood where we sell, right. So we have to re-tailor our capacities for the new demographic realities in this continent. That does not mean – it's a hard job, but that does not mean that there is no business.

To René's point, there is a vibrant consumer market here and they will continue to drink beer. We invest in brands, which have a disproportional contribution to value, not in the least place, the Heineken brand, but also new products. Think about cider. We have close to 50% of market here in the UK, good margins, growing addressing a part of the drinking population, which is not touching that much beer.

We do that also on the European continent. That's going to cater for growth. It's not going to happen overnight. Because you don't benefit like in India or Brazil that the magic equation, the so simple equation of saying population growth times economic growth times economic or political stability and that's the easy recipe for growth.

Game is a bit more complicated, but still high prices, high margins, fantastic cash flows, which also served our company to finance our extension in the emerging markets. And so I would really make a plea, not seeing Europe as a lost case for our business, that's for sure. And have a little bit look through the economic downturn, take the demographics into account, their effect, but we still have a very healthy business with very good return on invested capital in Europe.
With that, if you agree, I'd like to close meeting. Thank you all and invite you for a beer or a pint of cider. Thank you.
